definitions: artificial bait used in fishing to attract and catch fish
something that tempts or attracts someone to a particular place or action
examples: The angler attached a colorful lure to his fishing line
She caught the bass using a spinner lure yesterday
The lure of easy money drew many into the scam
Free samples served as a lure to attract customers

definitions: person who drinks alcohol excessively and habitually, often to the point of addiction
examples: The old lush stumbled out of the bar at closing time
Her uncle was a notorious lush who spent every evening drinking
The party was full of lushs who couldn't stop drinking
He became a lush after losing his job last year

definitions: strong sexual desire or attraction towards another person
passionate desire or craving for something, especially power or material possessions
examples: His lust for her consumed his thoughts day and night
The novel explores themes of forbidden lust and desire
The dictator's lust for power knew no bounds whatsoever
Her lust for adventure led her to travel the world

definitions: soft glow or shine on a smooth surface, especially of a mineral or fabric
brilliance, distinction, or glory that makes something special or admirable
examples: The pearl's natural luster made it extremely valuable
Regular polishing maintains the silver's original luster
The scandal tarnished the luster of his political career
The university added luster to its reputation through research

definitions: soft glow or shine on a smooth surface, especially of a mineral or fabric
brilliance, distinction, or glory that makes something special or admirable
examples: The silk fabric had a beautiful lustre in the sunlight
The gemstone's lustre indicated its high quality
Years of success added lustre to the company's brand
The award ceremony restored lustre to her acting career

definitions: plucked string instrument with a pear-shaped body and bent neck, popular in Renaissance music
examples: The minstrel played a haunting melody on his lute
She studied lute performance at the conservatory
The museum displayed a sixteenth-century Italian lute
Renaissance paintings often depict angels playing lutes

definitions: SI unit of illuminance equal to one lumen per square meter, measuring light intensity
examples: The office lighting measured five hundred lux at desk level
Photography studios require at least one thousand lux
The meter showed the room had insufficient lux for reading
Moonlight provides approximately one lux of illumination

definitions: state of great comfort and extravagant living involving expensive pleasures
item or service that is desirable but not necessary, often expensive and rare
examples: They lived in luxury in their mansion by the sea
The resort offered every luxury imaginable to its guests
Eating out was a luxury they could rarely afford
Designer handbags are luxury items for most people

definitions: sweet white translucent fruit with rough pink skin, native to China and Southeast Asia
examples: Fresh lychees are available at the Asian market downtown
The dessert featured lychees in sweet coconut milk
She peeled the lychee to reveal its juicy flesh
Canned lychees taste different from fresh ones

definitions: strongly alkaline solution of sodium or potassium hydroxide used in soap making and cleaning
examples: Traditional soap makers use lye mixed with animal fats
The plumber used lye to clear the clogged drain
Handle lye carefully because it can cause severe burns
Pretzels get their brown crust from a lye bath

definitions: act of deliberately making false statements with intent to deceive or mislead others
examples: His constant lying destroyed trust in their relationship
The investigation revealed a pattern of lying to investors
Pathological lying can be a symptom of certain disorders
She was fired for lying on her job application

definitions: clear fluid containing white blood cells that circulates through the lymphatic system, fighting infection
examples: Lymph carries infection-fighting cells throughout the body
The doctor examined her swollen lymph nodes carefully
Cancer cells can spread through the lymph system
Lymph drainage massage helps reduce swelling

definitions: cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system called lymphocytes
examples: The patient was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma last year
Lymphoma treatment often involves chemotherapy and radiation
Early detection of lymphoma improves treatment outcomes significantly
His lymphoma went into remission after six months

definitions: illegal execution by a mob, historically associated with racial violence in the United States
examples: The museum documented the history of lynching in America
Anti-lynching legislation was proposed multiple times in Congress
The lynching sparked nationwide protests and outrage
Journalists investigated lynchings despite threats to their safety

definitions: medium-sized wild cat with tufted ears, short tail, and large padded paws for walking on snow
examples: The lynx stalked silently through the snowy forest
Canada lynx populations depend on snowshoe hare numbers
Wildlife cameras captured footage of a rare Iberian lynx
The lynx's distinctive ear tufts help with hearing

definitions: stringed musical instrument like a small harp, used especially in ancient Greece
examples: Apollo is often depicted holding a golden lyre
The poet accompanied herself on the lyre
Archaeological excavations uncovered fragments of ancient lyres
The lyre symbolized music and poetry in Greek culture

definitions: words of a song, especially a popular song
short poem expressing personal feelings and emotions of the poet
examples: She memorized every lyric of her favorite song
The band writes their own lyrics and music
His lyric about lost love touched many readers
Modern lyric poetry often breaks traditional forms

definitions: quality of expressing deep personal emotion or observations in an imaginative and beautiful way
examples: The novelist's lyricism transformed ordinary scenes into poetry
Jazz musicians praised the lyricism of her saxophone playing
His paintings display a remarkable lyricism and sensitivity
The film's visual lyricism captivated audiences worldwide

definitions: person who writes the words for songs, especially popular or musical theater songs
examples: The lyricist collaborated with composers on Broadway musicals
She worked as a lyricist for major recording artists
Famous lyricists often partner with specific composers
The award honored the lyricist's contribution to music

definitions: waterproof raincoat, typically made of rubberized fabric
examples: He grabbed his mac before heading into the rain
The yellow mac kept her dry during the storm
School children wore macs over their uniforms
Her mac had a removable hood for sunny days

definitions: road surface made of layers of compacted broken stone, now usually bound with tar or asphalt
examples: The old macadam road needed urgent repairs
Workers laid fresh macadam on the highway
Rain pooled on the worn macadam surface
The macadam driveway lasted for decades

definitions: round, hard-shelled nut from an Australian tree, prized for its rich, buttery flavor
examples: Chocolate-covered macadamias are a popular Hawaiian souvenir
She added chopped macadamias to the cookie dough
Macadamia oil is used in cooking and cosmetics
The recipe calls for roasted macadamia nuts

definitions: tube-shaped pasta made from durum wheat, often used in macaroni and cheese dishes
examples: She boiled the macaroni for eight minutes until tender
The cafeteria served macaroni and cheese every Friday
Elbow macaroni works best for pasta salads
He bought three boxes of macaroni at the store

definitions: large, long-tailed, brightly colored parrot native to Central and South American rainforests
examples: The scarlet macaw spread its brilliant wings
Blue and gold macaws are popular in captivity
Wild macaws feed on fruits, nuts, and seeds
The sanctuary rescued injured macaws from trafficking

definitions: heavy club with a spiked metal head used as a weapon in medieval times
ornamental staff carried as a symbol of authority in ceremonies
spice made from the dried covering of nutmeg seeds
examples: Knights wielded maces to crush armor in battle
The museum displayed a medieval mace from the thirteenth century
The mayor carried the ceremonial mace during the procession
Parliament's golden mace represents royal authority
She added ground mace to the pumpkin pie filling
Mace has a slightly sweeter flavor than nutmeg

definitions: broad, heavy knife used as an implement or weapon, especially in tropical countries
examples: Workers cleared the jungle path with machetes
The farmer used a machete to harvest sugar cane
He sharpened his machete before cutting the bamboo
Machetes are essential tools in many tropical regions

definitions: apparatus using mechanical power and having parts that perform a particular task
efficient and powerful organization or structure that operates like a mechanical system
examples: The factory installed new machines to increase production
She operated the sewing machine with practiced ease
The political machine controlled city elections for decades
Their marketing machine generated millions in sales

definitions: machines collectively, especially those used in industrial or manufacturing processes
organized system or structure for achieving something, especially in government or business
examples: The factory's machinery required regular maintenance checks
Heavy machinery cleared the construction site
The machinery of government moved slowly through reforms
They dismantled the old machinery of corruption

definitions: person who operates machine tools to make or repair metal parts and equipment
examples: The machinist crafted precision parts for aircraft engines
She trained as a machinist at the technical college
Experienced machinists are in high demand nationwide
The machinist calibrated the lathe before starting work

definitions: strong or aggressive masculine pride and behavior, often characterized by dominance over women
examples: His machismo prevented him from admitting any weakness
The culture of machismo influenced workplace dynamics
Films often critique toxic machismo in modern society
Traditional machismo is being challenged by younger generations

definitions: man who displays aggressive masculine pride and strength, often in an exaggerated way
examples: The macho refused to ask for directions when lost
He played the macho hero in action movies
Office machos competed over who worked longest hours
Being a macho doesn't impress modern women

definitions: waterproof raincoat made from rubberized fabric
variety of red eating apple with crisp white flesh
examples: She wore her macintosh to protect against the drizzle
The old macintosh hung on the coat rack
Fresh macintosh apples filled the orchard baskets
He preferred macintosh apples for making pies

definitions: informal term for a mackintosh or waterproof raincoat
examples: Grab your mack because rain is forecast today
His old mack had seen better days
The child's bright yellow mack stood out in the crowd
She folded her mack into her backpack

definitions: streamlined food fish with wavy dark markings on its back, found in temperate and tropical seas
examples: Fresh mackerel tastes best when grilled simply
The fishing boat caught tons of mackerel
Smoked mackerel makes an excellent sandwich filling
Mackerel is rich in omega-3 fatty acids

definitions: full-length waterproof coat made from rubberized fabric, named after its Scottish inventor
examples: Victorian gentlemen wore mackintoshes in rainy weather
Her mackintosh kept her completely dry
The mackintosh revolutionized rainwear in the nineteenth century
He hung his wet mackintosh by the door

definitions: single instruction that expands automatically into a set of instructions to perform a task
large-scale or overall view of something, as opposed to details
examples: The spreadsheet macro automated the monthly calculations
She recorded a macro to format documents quickly
Looking at the macro picture reveals economic trends
The macro analysis ignored important local variations

definitions: horizontal line placed over a vowel to indicate it should be pronounced as a long sound
examples: The macron over the 'a' changes its pronunciation
Latin textbooks use macrons to show vowel length
Japanese romaji sometimes includes macrons for long vowels
The dictionary used a macron to indicate pronunciation

definitions: polite form of address for a woman, especially in formal situations
woman who manages a brothel or house of prostitution
examples: Good evening, madam, may I take your coat?
The letter began with 'Dear Madam' as greeting
The madam ran her establishment with strict rules
Police arrested the madam during the raid

definitions: French title equivalent to Mrs., used before a woman's surname or alone as respectful address
examples: Madame Curie won two Nobel Prizes for her research
The waiter addressed her as Madame throughout dinner
Madame President called the meeting to order
We visited Madame Tussauds wax museum in London

definitions: person who behaves in a wild, impulsive, or reckless manner without thinking of consequences
examples: The madcap led her friends on wild adventures
That madcap will try anything for a thrill
Young madcaps raced their cars through the streets
The movie featured a lovable madcap as protagonist

definitions: French title for an unmarried woman, equivalent to Miss in English
examples: Mademoiselle Dubois taught French at the academy
The letter was addressed to Mademoiselle Marie Laurent
Good morning, Mademoiselle, how may I help you?
Young mademoiselles attended the finishing school

definitions: place or situation of uproar, confusion, and chaos
former term for a mental hospital or psychiatric institution
examples: The shopping mall was a madhouse during holiday sales
Their house became a madhouse when relatives visited
Victorian madhouses often mistreated their patients terribly
The old madhouse was converted into apartments

definitions: person who is mentally ill or exhibits extremely irrational behavior
person who behaves in a wild, reckless, or dangerous manner
examples: The madman shouted incoherently at passing strangers
Doctors tried to help the poor madman
He drives like a madman on the highway
Only a madman would attempt that dangerous stunt

definitions: educational institution in Islamic countries where students study Islamic theology and religious law
examples: Students at the madrasa memorized the entire Quran
The ancient madrasa attracted scholars from distant lands
Modern madrasas combine religious and secular education
The madrasa provided free education to poor children

definitions: educational institution in Islamic countries where students study Islamic theology and religious law
examples: The madrasah taught both religious and modern subjects
She attended madrasah every afternoon after regular school
Historic madrasahs feature beautiful Islamic architecture
The madrasah system dates back many centuries

definitions: powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river that can pull objects down
situation or state of confused movement, violence, or turmoil
examples: Ships avoided the dangerous maelstrom near the rocks
The maelstrom sucked debris into its swirling center
Political events created a maelstrom of controversy
She found herself in a maelstrom of conflicting emotions

definitions: distinguished conductor or performer of classical music
master or expert in any art or field of activity
examples: The maestro raised his baton to begin the symphony
Young musicians studied under the famous maestro
He's a maestro in the kitchen, creating amazing dishes
The software maestro solved our technical problems quickly

definitions: organized international body of criminals, originally from Sicily, operating through violence and intimidation
group regarded as exerting hidden sinister influence in a particular sphere
examples: The mafia controlled illegal gambling in the city
Federal agents infiltrated the mafia organization
The corporate mafia blocked all attempts at reform
A mafia of critics controlled the art world

definitions: member of the mafia crime organization, especially one involved in organized criminal activities
examples: The mafioso operated several illegal businesses downtown
Former mafioso testified against his crime family
The young mafioso rose quickly through the ranks
Movies often romanticize the mafioso lifestyle

definitions: informal abbreviation for magazine, a periodical publication
examples: She bought a fashion mag at the newsstand
The mag featured celebrities on its cover
He subscribed to several car mags online
That mag always has interesting articles
